comment: Thank you sir. You just made my understanding of trigonometric identities a lot better.

I never understood why in the US they always teach students secant, cosecant and cotangent. I feel like they are never really that useful for more advanced topics and just add more confusion for students just learning about them.
came here because i misclicked from graphing functions, stayed for the pythagorean identity derivations. if this was how it was taught to me in 8th grade, i would've liked maths a bit.

Thanks so much for this video! i really appreciate the part where you derive the other pythagorean identities from that one identity. Our prof never really discussed the connection between the trigo identities so it was quite difficult to comprehend the need for these stuff to me but then I came across this vid so they made so MUCH sense now and it really helped me alot :))
This video is gold
3:48 sin 30 = cos 90 -30 (because of unit circle theorem)

If (sin θ)²+(cos θ)²=1, then does sqrt((sin θ)²+(cos θ)²)=(sin θ)²+(cos θ)² because sqrt(1)=1?

The Confusion Identities

Addressing Cofunction Identities: Why do we define them as e.g.  sin(θ) = cos(90° - θ) when we could also write: sin(θ) = cos(θ ± 90°) ?  I assume direction to which we shift the angle does not matter als long as we shift for exactly 90°.
